history: Angkor Wat is a temple complex in Cambodia and is the largest religious monument in the world. It was built in the early 12th century by King Suryavarman II as a Hindu temple dedicated to the god Vishnu. The temple later transformed into a Buddhist site by the end of the 12th century. Angkor Wat was built in the capital city of the Khmer Empire and served as a symbol of the empire's power and wealth. The complex covers an area of over 400 acres and is known for its intricate carvings and bas-reliefs.
Ecological Relevance: Angkor Wat is surrounded by a moat and is situated within the Angkor Archaeological Park, which is a UNESCO World Heritage site. The temple complex is nestled within a lush green forest, showcasing the harmonious relationship between human-made structures and nature. The site attracts millions of visitors each year, contributing to the conservation and protection of the surrounding ecosystem.

timeline.Details: Construction of Angkor Wat begins under King Suryavarman II.
Transformation of Angkor Wat from a Hindu temple to a Buddhist site.
Angkor Wat is abandoned as the capital shifts to Phnom Penh.
French explorers redicover Angkor Wat, bringing it to the attention of the Western world.
Angkor Wat undergoes restoration and conservation efforts to preserve its architectural and historical significance.
Angkor Wat becomes a UNESCO World Heritage Site, attracting tourists and researchers from around the globe.
Angkor Wat continues to be a symbol of Cambodian identity and cultural heritage, drawing visitors and scholars to study its architecture and history.
